script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Welcome to the Come Follow Me Podcast by Gospel Study App. I'm Sarah.

script.speaker: David
script.text: And I'm David. Happy to be here!

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: David, I’ve got a question that’s been nagging at me. What if I told you there’s a single phrase in Moses 1 that most people miss, but it unlocks the entire purpose of God’s creation? I’m curious—what’s hidden in plain sight here?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Oh, Sarah, that’s a fantastic place to start. There’s a moment in Moses 1:39 where the Lord says, ‘For behold, this is my work and my glory—to bring to pass the immortality and eternal life of man.’ Most people read that and move on, but if you pause, it’s a bombshell. It’s God’s mission statement—everything He does is for us.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Wait, a mission statement? That’s intriguing. So, are you saying every story, every covenant in the scriptures ties back to this one idea? I need to understand how this frames everything.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Exactly, Sarah. Think of it as the lens for the whole plan of salvation. From Moses seeing God’s creations to Abraham learning about premortal spirits, it all points to God’s purpose—our eternal life. Let’s unpack this through multiple perspectives to see how it shifts our view.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I’m all ears. Let’s start with Moses. How does his experience in Moses 1 show this purpose from, say, his perspective as a mortal, and then from God’s view?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Great question. From Moses’s perspective in Moses 1:30, he’s overwhelmed, asking, ‘Tell me … why these things are so.’ He’s seeing the vastness of creation and can’t grasp it as a mortal. But from God’s view in verse 39, it’s clear—every star, every soul exists to bring us to eternal life through Christ.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s powerful. So Moses is wrestling with the ‘why,’ and God answers with this ultimate purpose. Does this theme of eternal life echo across other dispensations, like in Abraham’s vision?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Absolutely, it does. In Abraham 3:24-25, the Lord explains the plan to create an earth where spirits can be tested, saying, ‘We will prove them herewith, to see if they will do all things whatsoever the Lord their God shall command them.’ It’s the same purpose—preparing us for eternal life. Notice how this pattern runs from premortal life to mortality, all the way to Christ’s Atonement.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I’m starting to see it. It’s like a thread weaving through time. Can we trace this idea of ‘proving’ or preparing for eternal life even further—maybe into the modern restoration?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Yes, let’s connect it. In the Doctrine and Covenants, we often see this purpose restated. For instance, in D&C 11:20, the Lord says, ‘Behold, this is your work, to keep my commandments, yea, with all your might, mind and strength.’ It mirrors Abraham’s ‘prove them herewith’—our mortal test is part of God’s glory to bring us home.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s remarkable! So this purpose isn’t just ancient—it’s for us now. I’m curious, David, is there any historical or cultural context from Moses’s time that makes this even more vivid?

script.speaker: David
script.text: There is, and here’s where it gets fascinating. In Moses’s era, around the 13th or 14th century BC, ancient Near Eastern cultures often saw gods as distant, uncaring, or focused on their own power. But in Moses 1, God reveals Himself as intimately invested in humanity—calling Moses ‘my son’ in verse 6. That personal relationship, tied to eternal life, would’ve been revolutionary to Moses and the Israelites.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Wow, that creates such a ‘time collapse’ moment for me. To think God’s care for us was so countercultural back then—it makes His purpose feel even more personal. So, going back to that bombshell in Moses 1:39, how does it fully answer the ‘why’ of creation?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Here’s where it gets powerful, Sarah. God isn’t just creating for the sake of creating—His work and glory are us. Immortality comes through Christ’s Resurrection, but eternal life, living with God, comes through our choices and His grace. Moses 1:39 reveals that every part of the plan, from premortality to the final judgment, is designed for our divine destiny.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s the ‘aha’ I was waiting for. It’s all about us becoming like Him. Now, are there any hidden connections in these chapters that most people might miss, tying this purpose to other scriptures?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Definitely. Look at Abraham 3:22-23, where the Lord shows Abraham the noble and great spirits, including Christ, chosen before the world was. Now connect that to Moses 1:6, where God tells Moses, ‘Thou art in the similitude of mine Only Begotten.’ Both point to Christ as central to the plan—He’s the key to eternal life.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I never noticed that link before! So Christ is woven into both visions, not just as Savior but as the pattern for our potential. That’s mind-blowing.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Exactly! And here’s another layer—Satan tries to derail this in Moses 1:12 by saying, ‘Moses, son of man, worship me.’ He’s attacking Moses’s divine identity, the very thing God affirms, to stop him from fulfilling his part in the plan.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s such a striking contrast. God builds us up as His children; Satan tears that down. How can understanding this purpose and our identity apply to us today, David?

script.speaker: David
script.text: It’s everything, Sarah. Knowing we’re children of God, as Moses 1:4 teaches, shapes our choices. President Russell M. Nelson said in his talk ‘Choices for Eternity’ that how we think about our identity affects every decision. When we see ourselves as part of God’s work and glory, we resist counterfeits and align with His plan.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s so practical. It’s not just theology—it’s a daily guide. So, what’s one thing we can do to keep this purpose front and center in our lives?

script.speaker: David
script.text: I’d invite everyone to ponder Moses 1:39 this week. Read it slowly, and ask, ‘How does God see me as part of His glory?’ Let that truth sink in, and notice how it changes the way you face challenges or make choices. It’s a perspective that can transform everything.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I love that invitation, David. Thank you for unpacking this profound idea with me. I’m walking away seeing God’s plan in a whole new light.
